DT Article
TI Indo-West Pacific species of Trachinotus with spots on their sides as
   adults, with description of a new species endemic to the Marquesas
   Islands (Teleostei: Carangidae).
AU Smith-Vaniz, William F. (smithvaniz@gmail.com) 
   Walsh, Stephen J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 1-37
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Diagnoses, comparisons, photographs and distribution maps are given for
   three previously described Indo-West Pacific species of Trachinotus that
   develop spots on their sides as adults. A new species, Trachinotus
   macrospilus, is described from the Marquesas Islands where it is endemic
   and the only species of the genus present. It differs from the other
   spotted Indo-West Pacific species most noticeably in having adults with
   only one or two large spots on each side, the largest spot larger than
   the iris diameter, and in having no large spot positioned above the
   pectoral fin. An identification key is given for all Indo-West Pacific
   species of Trachinotus and a molecular phylogeny, including 16 of the 20
   valid species of Trachinotus is presented. A neotype is designated for
   Scomber botla Shaw, 1803.
C1 Smith-Vaniz, William F.; Univ Florida, Florida Museum Nat Hist,
   Gainesville, FL, 32611, USA, USA.
EM smithvaniz@gmail.com
RI Walsh, Stephen/AAE-9578-2019

   /  / distribution] [Pacific Ocean /  / ] [ /  / ]. 
   Trachinotus macrospilus [South Pacific / Marquesas Islands / New
   species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates

   Pacific, P. 27]. 
   Trachinotus macrospilus (Carangidae): [Sp nov, Marquesas Islands
   (marine), P. 5]. 
   Scomber botla - Shaw 1803 (Scombridae): [Neotype designated, P. 18].

DT Article
TI Cambarus fetzneri sp. nov., a new species of burrowing crayfish
   (Decapoda: Cambaridae) from the Allegheny Mountains of Virginia and West
   Virginia, USA.
AU Loughman, Zachary J. (zloughman@westliberty.edu) 
   Welsh, Stuart A.
   Thoma, Roger F.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 38-50
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 2
U2 4
AB The disjunct distribution of Cambarus monongalensis has led to
   speculation about its taxonomic status. An Appalachian Plateau
   population occurs in northern and central West Virginia and Southwestern
   Pennsylvania, and a mountain population occurs in the Allegheny
   Mountains and Ridge and Valley physiographic provinces of the Virginias.
   Herein we describe the mountain population as Cambarus fetzneri sp. nov.
   The two species differ genetically and morphologically, and have
   different color patterns. Specifically, C. fetzneri sp. nov. chelae lack
   extensive red coloration on the distal end of the propodus and dactyl,
   possess rostral margins that lack any red coloration, compared to C.
   monongalensis, which has extensive red coloration on the dactyl and
   propodus, as well as red rostral margins. Morphologically, the rostrum
   of C. fetzneri sp. nov. is shorter and wider than that of C.
   monongalensis. Also, adult C. fetzneri sp. nov. are considerably smaller
   in body size than those of C. monongalensis.
C1 Loughman, Zachary J.; West Liberty Univ, Dept Nat Sci & Math, CSC Box
   139, West Liberty, WV, 26074, USA, USA.
EM zloughman@westliberty.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA
DE Cambarus fetzneri [Virginia /  / New species] [West Virginia /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Astacura
OR Cambarus fetzneri (Astacura): [Sp nov, West Virginia, P. 41].

DT Article
TI On three symbiotic species of the alpheid shrimp genus Salmoneus
   Holthuis, 1955 from the Indo-West Pacific, including one new to science
   (Malacostraca: Decapoda: Caridea).
AU Anker, Arthur (arthuranker7@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 51-63
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three species of the alpheid shrimp genus Salmoneus Holthuis, 1955
   associated with burrows of other decapod crustaceans are reported from
   various Indo-West Pacific localities. Salmoneus venustus sp. nov. is
   described based on material collected at two distant localities, Nha
   Trang Bay, southern Vietnam, the type locality of the new species, and
   the Yiti-Sifah region east of Muscat, northern Oman. Both specimens were
   collected with the aid of a suction pump applied to burrow entrances or
   mounds in muddy sand; the holotype was possibly associated with burrows
   of the callianassid ghost shrimp, Glypturus sp. Salmoneus venustus sp.
   nov. shares many characteristics with S. latirostris (Coutiere, 1897),
   including the red banding of the pleon, but can be distinguished from S.
   latirostris and all other species of the genus by a unique combination
   of morphological characters. The large-sized Salmoneus brucei Komai,
   2009 is reported from Sumba, central Indonesia, representing a
   significant southward extension of the species' previously known
   distribution range and the first record since its original description.
   The callianassid ghost shrimp Lepidophthalmus cf. rosae (Nobili, 1904)
   is recorded as a new host of S. brucei. Finally, Salmoneus colinorum De
   Grave, 2004, associated with burrows of larger snapping shrimps from the
   Alpheus malabaricus Fabricius, 1798 species complex, is reported for the
   first time from Madang, Papua New Guinea, representing an eastward
   extension of the species' previously known distribution range.
C1 Anker, Arthur; Univ Fed Goias, Inst Ciencias Biol, Campus Samambaia,ICB
   5,Ave Esperanca S-N, Goiania, Go, BR-74690900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM arthuranker7@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Ocean; North Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean
DE Alpheus malabaricus [Nest and burrow fauna / Salmoneus colinorum
   (Crustacea) / New record; associate systematics] [South Pacific / Papua
   New Guinea, Madang / Crustacean burrow associates]. 
   Glypturus [Nest and burrow fauna / Salmoneus venustus (Crustacea) / New
   burrow associate species] [North Pacific / Vietnam / New burrow
   associated crustacean species]. 
   Lepidophthalmus tridentatus [Nest and burrow fauna / Salmoneus brucei
   (Crustacea) / New record; associate systematics] [South Pacific /
   Indonesia / Crustacean burrow associates]. 
   Salmoneus brucei [Nest and burrow fauna / Lepidophthalmus tridentatus
   (Crustacea) / New record; systematics] [South Pacific / Indonesia /
   Crustacean burrow associates]. 
   Salmoneus colinorum [Nest and burrow fauna / Alpheus malabaricus
   (Crustacea) / New record; systematics] [South Pacific / Papua New
   Guinea, Madang / Crustacean burrow associates]. 
   Salmoneus venustus [Nest and burrow fauna / Glypturus (Crustacea) / New
   burrow associate species] [Persian Gulf / Oman / New species] [North
   Pacific / Vietnam / New species from crustacean burrow]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Decapoda, Natantia, Reptantia, Anomura

   Salmoneus brucei - Komai 2009 (Natantia): [New record]. 
   Salmoneus colinorum - De Grave 2004 (Natantia): [New record]. 
   Salmoneus venustus (Natantia): [Sp nov, Vietnam (marine), Burrow
   associate of Glypturus (Crustacea), p. 52]. 
   Glypturus (Anomura). 
   Lepidophthalmus tridentatus (Anomura): [New record].

DT Article
TI Salmoneus durisi sp. nov., an infaunal alpheid shrimp probably
   associated with callianassid ghost shrimps in the tropical Indo-West
   Pacific (Malacostraca: Decapoda: Caridea).
AU Anker, Arthur (arthuranker7@gmail.com) 
   Ashrafi, Hossein
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 64-74
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of the alpheid shrimp genus Salmoneus Holthuis, 1955,
   probably an obligate associate of ghost shrimp burrows, is described
   based on material from Oman (type locality: Darsait near Muscat), Iran
   and the Philippines. Salmoneus durisi sp. nov. is characterised
   principally by both chelipeds enlarged, robust, with ventral and dorsal
   margins of chelae carrying long fine setae, and with minor chela fingers
   armed with a few large teeth on cutting edges. All specimens of
   Salmoneus durisi sp. nov. were collected either directly from burrows of
   larger decapod crustaceans with the aid of a suction pump, or by
   exposing burrows dug under large subtidal rocks. The Iranian specimen
   was found together with its presumed host, Neocallichirus calmani
   (Nobili, 1904). Two additional specimens from Indonesia and the Solomon
   Islands are tentatively assigned to S. cf. durisi sp. nov., awaiting
   further studies.
C1 Anker, Arthur; Univ Fed Goias, Inst Ciencias Biol, Campus Samambaia,ICB
   5,Ave Esperanca S-N, Goiania, Go, BR-74690900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM arthuranker7@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Marine zones; Indian
   Ocean; North Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean
DE Neocallichirus calmani [Associations / Salmoneus durisi (Crustacea) /
   New associate species] [Persian Gulf / Iran / New associated crustacean
   species]. 
   Salmoneus durisi [Associations / Neocallichirus calmani (Crustacea) /
   New associate species] [Persian Gulf / Iran / New species; crustacean
   associate] [ / Oman / ] [North Pacific / Philippines / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Decapoda, Natantia, Reptantia, Anomura

   Neocallichirus calmani (Anomura).

DT Article
TI Alpheus perlas, sp. nov., a new infaunal snapping shrimp from the
   Pacific coast of Panama (Malacostraca: Decapoda: Alpheidae).
AU Anker, Arthur (arthuranker7@gmail.com) 
   Pachelle, Paulo P.G.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 75-84
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new snapping shrimp, Alpheus perlas sp. nov., is described based on a
   single complete male specimen collected on a shallow mudflat at Casayeta
   Island in the Las Perlas Archipelago, Gulf of Panama. The new species
   belongs to the large A. edwardsii (Audouin, 1821) species group
   characterised essentially by the presence of two notches on the major
   chela palm, with the dorsal notch extending posteriorly on the mesial
   surface. Within the eastern Pacific members of the A. edwardsii group,
   A. perlas sp. nov. appears to be morphologically closest to A. latus
   Kim&Abele, 1988 and A. burukovskyi Anker&Pachelle, 2015. Alpheus perlas
   sp. nov. does not seem to be specially adapted for digging and may be
   inquiline of a larger burrowing host, which currently remains unknown
C1 Anker, Arthur; UFG, Inst Ciencias Biol, Campus Samambaia,ICB 5,Ave
   Esperanca S-N, Goiania, Go, BR-74690900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM arthuranker7@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

DT Article
TI Description of Ditylenchus paraparvus n. sp. from Iran with an updated
   list of Ditylenchus Filipjev, 1936 (Nematoda: Anguinidae).
AU Hashemi, Kobra
   Karegar, Akbar (kobra.hashemi@yahoo.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 85-113
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 4
U2 6
AB During a survey, 12 known and one new species of Ditylenchus Filipjev,
   1936 were collected from southern provinces of Iran during 2013-2017.
   Ditylenchus paraparvus n. sp. is characterised by a short body length
   (441-543 [mu]m), lateral field with four lines, delicate and short
   stylet (6-7.5 [mu]m) with small rounded or posteriorly sloping knobs,
   pyriform and offset basal pharyngeal bulb, V = 67.7-76.4, short
   post-vulval uterine sac less than one vulval body width long, small
   spicules (12.5-15 [mu]m) and almost cylindrical tail (71-90 [mu]m) with
   rounded end. Morphometric data of studied species are presented and
   intraspecific variation of their morphometrics and morphological
   characters is discussed. The list of the world Ditylenchus species is
   updated, and a dichotomous identification key and an updated tabular
   compendium for 63 valid species is provided.
C1 Karegar, Akbar; Shiraz Univ, Sch Agr, Shiraz, Iran, Iran.
EM kobra.hashemi@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Documentation; Publications; Biometrics; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Ditylenchus [Checklists / Updated species list / systematics]
   [Biometrics / Morphometrics / ]. 
   Ditylenchus paraparvus [Iran /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes

   subordinate taxa, Species, p. 98; Emended diagnosis, P. 101; Key to

   inquirenda, P. 106].

DT Article
TI Three new species of the spider family Pholcidae (Arachnida: Araneae)
   from Taita-Taveta, Kenya.
AU Yao, Zhiyuan
   Kioko, Grace M.
   Kioko, Esther N.
   Li, Shuqiang (lisq@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 114-124
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Only nine species of the spider family Pholcidae C. L. Koch, 1850 are
   endemic in Kenya. In this study, three new species from Taita-Taveta
   County, southern Kenya are reported. They belong to two genera of the
   pholcid spiders: Buitinga qingyuani Yao&Li sp. nov. (male, female), B.
   wamitii Yao&Li sp. nov. (male), and Smeringopus voi Yao&Li sp. nov.
   (male, female). All material studied is deposited in the National
   Museums of Kenya (NMK) in Nairobi, Kenya.
C1 Li, Shuqiang; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Beijing, 100101, China,
   China.

   species].

DT Article
TI The eastern Pacific species of Salmoneus Holthuis, 1955, with
   description of a remarkable new species from Las Perlas Archipelago,
   Panama (Malacostraca: Decapoda: Alpheidae).
AU Anker, Arthur (arthuranker7@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 125-140
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The present study deals with five species of the alpheid shrimp genus
   Salmoneus Holthuis, 1955 from the tropical eastern Pacific. One of them
   is new to science and is described as Salmoneus tiburon sp. nov. The new
   species is presently known only from the Las Perlas Archipelago in
   Panama and can be distinguished from all other congeners by the
   dentition on the cutting edges of the major chela, with some dactylar
   teeth reminiscent of shark teeth. It is also one of the largest species
   of the genus, with the carapace length of both type specimens surpassing
   8.0 mm. Salmoneus serratidigitus (Coutiere, 1897), a species with an
   ample distribution across the Indo-Pacific, is recorded for the first
   time from the Pacific coast of Panama and is confirmed from Colombia.
   Salmoneus malagensis Anker&Lazarus, 2015, previously known only from
   Bahia Malaga in Colombia, is recorded from Panama's Azuero Peninsula.
   The remaining two species, S. excavatus Anker, 2011 and S. alvarezi
   Anker&Lazarus, 2015, are recorded regionally from Las Perlas Archipelago
   in Panama and Playa Tarcoles in Costa Rica, both for the first time
   since their original descriptions. An identification key to the five
   currently known eastern Pacific species of Salmoneus is provided.
   However, several immature and/or incomplete specimens herein
   preliminarily reported as Salmoneus spp., as well photographic records
   from southern California, USA, indicate the presence of further
   undescribed species in the eastern Pacific.
C1 Anker, Arthur; UFG, Inst Ciencias Biol, Campus Samambaia,ICB 5,Ave
   Esperanca S-N, Goiania, Go, BR-74690900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM arthuranker7@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Salmoneus [Pacific Ocean / East / Key to species] [ /  / Faunal list;
   new record; systematics]. 
   Salmoneus malagensis; Salmoneus serratidigitus [North Pacific / Panama /
   New record; systematics]. 
   Salmoneus tiburon [North Pacific / Panama / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Natantia
OR Salmoneus - Holthuis 1955 (Natantia): [Key to species, Pacific Ocean,
   East, P. 138; New record]. 
   Salmoneus malagensis - Anker & Lazarus 2015 (Natantia): [New record]. 
   Salmoneus serratidigitus - (Coutiere 1897) (Natantia): [New record]. 
   Salmoneus tiburon (Natantia): [Sp nov, Panama (marine), P. 126].

DT Article
TI Phylogenetic relationships within the Frankliniella genus-group based on
   morphology, with a revision of Iridothrips (Thysanoptera, Thripidae).
AU Wang, Zhaohong
   Mound, Laurence
   Tong, Xiaoli (laurence.mound@csiro.au) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 141-154
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Frankliniella genus-group comprises over 270 species in ten genera.
   It is one of the important groups in Thripinae, and includes some
   important pests. A phylogenetic analysis of genus-level relationships
   within the Frankliniella genus-group was performed, based on 55
   morphological character states scored for 23 species representing 11
   genera, including an outgroup, Thrips physapus. Six most parsimonious
   trees were generated from the analysis under equal weighting schemes.
   Pseudanaphothrips was recovered as monophyletic, and as sister group to
   a clade comprising five genera, Yaobinthrips, Parabaliothrips,
   Sitothrips, Firmothrips, Kakothrips, in which Parabaliothrips showed to
   be a paraphyletic group. Frankliniella was paraphyletic, with
   Frankliniella zizaniophila + Iridothrips + Pelikanothrips kratochvili
   forming one clade that was sister group to the rest of the species of
   Frankliniella + Guerothrips moundi. According to the phylogenetic
   analysis, Guerothrips is proposed as a new synonym of Frankliniella, and
   Pelikanothrips is considered a new synonym of Iridothrips. The genus
   Iridothrips is revised with a key to five species, including I.
   zizaniophila comb. n., I. kratochvili comb. n. and I. lobulatus sp.n.. A
   key to the eight members of the Frankliniella genus-group is provided.
C1 Tong, Xiaoli; South China Agr Univ, Coll Agr, Guangzhou, Guangdong,
   510642, China, China.
EM laurence.mound@csiro.au
RI Mound, Laurence A/A-3967-2009
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Taxonomic position; Key; General morphology; Evolution; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia; China
DE Frankliniella genus group [General morphology / Morphological characters
   / systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Plant hosts /  / ]. 
   Iridothrips lobulatus [Plant hosts / Themeda / New parasite species]
   [Shandong /  / New species from plant host]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Thysanoptera
OR Frankliniella (Thysanoptera): [Syn nov, Guerothrips Goldarazena &
   Infante 2013, p. 141]. 
   Frankliniella genus group (Thysanoptera): [Key to genera, P. 145;
   Parasite]. 
   Frankliniella zizaniophila - Han & Zhang 1982 (Thysanoptera): [Referred
   to, Iridothrips, p. 152]. 
   Iridothrips - Priesner 1940 (Thysanoptera): [Syn nov, Pelikanothrips
   Bhatti 1978, p. 145; Key to species, Females, p. 148]. 
   Iridothrips kratochvili - (Pelikan 1947) (Thysanoptera): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Pelikanothrips, p. 148]. 
   Iridothrips lobulatus (Thysanoptera): [Sp nov, Shandong, Parasite of
   Themeda (Plant), p. 148; Parasite]. 
   Iridothrips zizaniophila - (Han & Zhang 1982) (Thysanoptera): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Frankliniella, p. 152]. 
   Pelikanothrips kratochvili - (Pelikan 1947) (Thysanoptera): [Referred
   to, Iridothrips, p. 148].

DT Article
TI New genus and species of cockroaches from the tribe Brachycolini
   (Blattaria: Blaberidae: Blaberinae) and redescription of the Hormetica
   strumosa.
AU Vidlicka, L'ubomir (lubomir.vidlicka@savba.sk) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 155-172
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB From the tribe Brachycolini Beier, 1961 new genus with one species
   Quadrihormetica onorei Vidlicka, gen. et sp. n. and species
   Lucihormetica yasuniana Vidlicka, sp. n. from the region Oriente
   (Amazon), Ecuador are described. The new genus is clearly distinguished
   from all other genera by specific shape of pronotum. The male of
   Hormetica strumosa is redescribed and illustrated; his female is the
   first time described.
C1 Vidlicka, L'ubomir; Slovak Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Dubravska Cesta 9,
   Bratislava, 84506, Slovakia, Slovakia.
EM lubomir.vidlicka@savba.sk
SC Zoology

BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones;

DE Lucihormetica yasuniana; Quadrihormetica onorei [Ecuador /  / New
   species].

DT Article
TI Leiocassis rudicula (Teleostei: Siluriformes: Bagridae), a new catfish
   from eastern Borneo.
AU Ng, Heok Hee (heokhee.ng@gmail.com) 
   Hadiaty, Renny K.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4651
IS 1
PS 191-200
PD Aug 2 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 7
AB A new species of bagrid catfish in the genus Leiocassis is described
   from the Mahakam River drainage in eastern Borneo. Leiocassis rudicula,
   new species, can be distinguished from congeners in having a unique
   combination of: distinct concavity at level of orbit in dorsolateral
   profile of head; tip of supraoccipital spine not reaching anterior
   nuchal plate element; smooth posterior margin of dorsal spine; presence
   of an irregular pale band on sides of body between dorsal and adipose
   fins; anal fin with narrow brown band across middle third of fin; narrow
   caudal-fin lobes with nearly straight posterior margins; snout length
   36-40% HL; eye diameter 14-20% HL; head depth 17.6-20.0% SL; length of
   dorsal-fin spine 14.1-18.5% SL; length of pectoral-fin spine 15.1-17.7 %
   SL; dorsal-to-adipose distance 10.9-14.3% SL; body depth at anus
   16.4-19.5% SL; length of adipose-fin base 18.9-24.1% SL; length of
   anal-fin base 18.8-22.6% SL; and caudal peduncle depth 9.1-10.9% SL. A
   revised key to the genus is also provided.
C1 Ng, Heok Hee; Lee Kong Chian Nat Hist Museum, 2 Conservatory Dr,
   Singapore, 117377, Singapore, Singapore.
EM heokhee.ng@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   region; Eurasia; Asia

TI More on the morphological characteristics and systematic texology of
   genus Longfengshania Du, 1982 (Magascopic Alga).
AU Niu, Shaowu (402416024@qq.com) 
SO Dizhi Tongbao
VL 38
IS 8
PS 1259-1265
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The fossil bodies of Longfengshania are composed of the tow part with
   foliate and sub-leafstalk fixed organs, and thus the author considers
   that the genus represents the fossils of marine sessile multicellular
   Mataphyta with possible relationships to the Phaeophyta and Chlophyta.
   According to the morphological characteristics, biogenetic law and
   palaeoecology, the algal body of genus Longfengshania Du is composed of
   three parts with blade, stripe and holdfast, belonging to Phyllum
   Phaeophyta, Order Laminariales, Family Longfenphaniaceae. The initial
   solution of systematic texology of genus Longfengshania Du is of
   important significance in the study of biology and palaeontology.
C1 Niu, Shaowu; China Geol Survey, Tianjin Inst Geol & Mineral Resources,
   Tianjin, 300170, China, China.
EM 402416024@qq.com

DT Article
TI Revision of the extant Polypteridae (Actinopterygii: Cladistia).
AU Moritz, Timo (timo.moritz@outlook.com) 
   Britz, Ralf
SO Ichthyological Exploration of Freshwaters
VL 29
IS 2
PS 97-192
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species-level taxonomy of all extant members of the family
   Polypteridae is revised. Two genera are recognised: Polypterus and the
   monotypic Erpetoichthys. Thirteen species of Polypterus are regarded as
   valid: P. bichir (type species), P. ansorgii, P. congicus, P. delhezi,
   P. endlicherii, P. mokelembembe, P. ornatipinnis, P. palmas, P. polli,
   P. retropinnis, P. senegalus, P. teugelsi and P. weeksii. Polypterus
   lapradei and P. bichir katangae are considered junior synonyms of P.
   bichir. Polypterus senegalus meridionalis is synonymized with P.
   senegalus, and P. buettikoferi and P. retropinnis lowei are regarded as
   junior synonyms of P. palmas. Lectotypes of P. ansorgii, P. congicus and
   P. delhezi are designated. Distribution maps for each species are
   compiled and a key for all species of Polypteridae is provided.
C1 Moritz, Timo; Deutsch Meeresmuseum, Katharinenberg 14-20, Stralsund,
   D-18439, Germany, Germany.
EM timo.moritz@outlook.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0936-9902
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key;
   Biometrics; General morphology; Skeletal and supporting structures; Land
   zones; Afrotropical region
DE Polypteridae [Biometrics / Skeletal morphometrics / taxonomic revision;
   extant taxa] [General morphology /  / ] [Skeleton /  / ] [Africa /  /
   distribution]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Polypteriformes, Polypteridae
OR Polypteridae (Polypteriformes): [Key to species, P. 187]. 
   Polypterus ansorgii - Boulenger 1910 (Polypteridae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 113]. 
   Polypterus bichir - (Geoffroy 1802) (Polypteridae): [Syn nov, Polypterus
   bichir katangae Poll 1941, p. 125; Syn nov, Polypterus lapradei
   Steindachner 1869, p. 125]. 
   Polypterus congicus - Boulenger 1898 (Polypteridae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 130]. 
   Polypterus delhezi - Boulenger 1899 (Polypteridae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 134]. 
   Polypterus palmas - Ayres 1850 (Polypteridae): [Syn nov, Polypterus
   buettikoferi Steindachner 1891, p. 150; Syn nov, Polypterus retropinnis
   lowei Boulenger 1911, p. 156].

DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15603014544
DT Article
TI Asiatic Waterside Skinks, Tropidophorus Dumeril and Bibron, 1839. A long
   overdue break up of the archaic genus sensu-lato, resulting in a total
   of eight genera, three resurrected from synonymy, four named for the
   first time and the additional descriptions of three new species.
AU Hoser, Raymond T. (snakeman@snakeman.com.au) 
SO Australasian Journal of Herpetology
VL 41
PS 5-17
PD Aug 1 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Asiatic Waterside Skinks, Tropidophorus Dumeril and Bibron, 1839 as
   recognized by herpetologists in year 2019 are a broadly monophyletic
   group, but including several divergent lineages of deep antiquity. As
   numerous molecular studies have confirmed these relevant groups all
   diverged at least 10-15 MYA or similar (e.g. Honda et al. 2006, Pui et
   al. 2017, Pyron et al. 2013), it is appropriate that all be recognized
   as separate genera. To that effect, this paper does just that. In
   assigning formal names to each divergent group of species, three names
   are resurrected from synonymy and four new genera are created in
   accordance with the rules of the International Code of Zoological
   Nomenclature (Ride et al. 1999). Another divergent lineage is also
   formally named as a subgenus. Three divergent species within the
   assemblage are also formally named for the first time.
C1 Hoser, Raymond T.; 488 Pk Rd, Pk Orchards, Vic, 3134, Australia,
   Australia.
EM snakeman@snakeman.com.au
SC Zoology
SN 1836-5698
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   Aspris russellgranti [Thailand /  / New species]. 
   Tropidophorus joeymontebelloi [Cambodia /  / New species] [Laos /  / ]
   [Vietnam /  / ] [River Mekong /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15603014545
DT Article
TI Further dismemberment of the pan-continental Lizard genus Scincella
   Mittleman, 1950 with the creation of four new genera to accommodate
   divergent species and the formal descriptions of six new species.
AU Hoser, Raymond T. (snakeman@snakeman.com.au) 
SO Australasian Journal of Herpetology
VL 41
PS 18-28
PD Aug 1 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Scincella Mittleman, 1950 as currently recognized has been
   shown in numerous studies to be paraphyletic. Since the creation of the
   genus, some divergent species have been split off into separate genera
   (e.g. Kaestlea Eremchenko and Das, 2004 and Asymblepharus Eremchenko and
   Szczerbak, 1980) or transferred to others. Continuing with this
   dismemberment of the genus, this paper relies on both morphological and
   molecular evidence to further refine the genus-level classification of
   Scincella sensu lato. Four new genera for Asiatic species are formally
   erected according to the rules of the International Code of Zoological
   Nomenclature (Ride et al. 1999) as well as two subgenera within one of
   the new genera. Six obviously unnamed species are also formally named in
   this paper, so that their conservation and management can be properly
   implemented and before any species runs the increased risk of becoming
   extinct through indifference both by the scientific community and
   regulatory authorities who depend on them. Included in this group are
   two species within the genus Asymblepharus. Four other species from
   Taiwan and a nearby island, until now treated as various other species
   of "Scincella" are formally named for the first time.
C1 Hoser, Raymond T.; 488 Pk Rd, Pk Orchards, Vic, 3134, Australia,
   Australia.
EM snakeman@snakeman.com.au
SC Zoology
SN 1836-5698
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Asymblepharus aurisovalibus [Nepal /  / New species]. 
   Asymblepharus lateralibusdorsoclavo [Jammu and Kashmir /  / New
   species]. 
   Ferescincella flavolateralis; Ferescincella insignipicturaconlus;
   Ferescincella ventrealbis [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
   Ferescincella yonagunijimaensis [Japan /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Scincidae
OR Asiascincella (Scincidae): [Gen nov, Type species Tiliqua reevesii Gray
   1838, p. 19]. 
   Asiascincella (Ovipacincella) (Scincidae): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Lygosoma melanostictum Boulenger 1887, p. 20, Also spelt Asiascincella
   (Ovipascincella)]. 
   Asiascincella (Ovipacincella) kohtaoensis - (Cochran 1927) (Scincidae):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Scincella, p. 21].

   (Scincidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from Scincella, p. 20]. 
   Asiascincella (Ovipacincella) nigrofasciata - (Neang, Chan & Poyarkov
   2018) (Scincidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from Scincella, p. 21]. 
   Asiascincella (Ovipacincella) ochracea - (Bourret 1937) (Scincidae):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Scincella, p. 21]. 
   Asiascincella (Ovipacincella) rufocaudata - (Darevsky & Nguyen Van Sang
   1983) (Scincidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from Scincella, p. 21]. 
   Asiascincella (Ovipacincella) rupicola - (Smith 1916) (Scincidae): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Scincella, p. 21]. 
   Asiascincella (Sinoscincella) (Scincidae): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Lygosoma doriae Boulenger 1887, p. 21]. 
   Asiascincella (Sinoscincella) doriae - (Boulenger 1887) (Scincidae):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Scincella, p. 21]. 
   Asiascincella doriae - (Boulenger 1887) (Scincidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Scincella, p. 20]. 
   Asiascincella huanrenensis - (Zhao & Huang 1982) (Scincidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Scincella, p. 20]. 
   Asiascincella reevesii - (Gray 1838) (Scincidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Scincella, p. 20].

UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15603014545
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15603014546
DT Article
TI Six new genera of skinks associated with Lipinia Gray, 1845 based on
   morphological and evolutionary divergence as well as twenty seven
   previously undiagnosed species within the same assemblage.
AU Hoser, Raymond T. (snakeman@snakeman.com.au) 
SO Australasian Journal of Herpetology
VL 41
PS 29-61
PD Aug 1 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An ongoing audit of the genus-level classification of the Lygosominae
   skinks for the genus Lipinia Gray, 1845 and associated species was
   conducted. It found that the genus-level classification as used in 2019
   did not reflect relationships between species or even morphological
   similarities between groups. As a result of these discrepancies, a new
   classification framework for the relevant species is given here. This
   includes reassignment of species between genera, including via
   resurrection of old and available names as well as the formal erection
   of six new genera in accordance with the International Code of
   Zoological Nomenclature (Ride et al. 1999) to accommodate divergent
   taxa. The new taxonomy and nomenclature is based on peer reviewed
   scientific evidence. This includes both morphological and molecular
   evidence as cited and because of this, it is robust and likely to
   substantively withstand the test of time. The audit also found
   significant underestimation of the species-level diversity within these
   genera and twenty seven of these unnamed taxa are formally named for the
   first time.
C1 Hoser, Raymond T.; 488 Pk Rd, Pk Orchards, Vic, 3134, Australia,
   Australia.
EM snakeman@snakeman.com.au
SC Zoology
SN 1836-5698
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Australasia;
   Oceanic islands; Indian Ocean islands; Pacific Ocean islands

DT Article
TI First record of the Madeira mealybug, Phenacoccus madeirensis Green
   (Hemiptera: Pseudococcidae), in Jordan.
AU Katbeh-Bader, A. (ahmadk@ju.edu.jo) 
   Al-Jboory, I.J.
   Kaydan, M. Bora
SO Bulletin OEPP
VL 49
IS 2
PS 401-404
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Madeira mealybug, Phenacoccus madeirensis (Hemiptera:
   Pseudococcidae), is recorded from Jordan for the first time. Specimens
   were collected from heavily infested ornamental geranium plants,
   Pelargonium sp. (Geraniaceae), Chrysanthemum sp. (Asteroideae), Hibiscus
   rosa-sinensis L. (Malvaceae), Kalanchoe blossfeldiana Poellnitz
   (Crassulaceae) and basil, Ocimum basilicum L. (Lamiaceae). In addition,
   this mealybug was taken from infested leaves of cherry tomato, Solanum
   lycopersicum L., and sweet pepper, Capsicum annuum L. (Solanaceae).
   Kalanchoe blossfeldiana is recorded as a new host for P. madeirensis.
   Slide mounts were prepared, and voucher specimens were preserved at the
   University of Jordan Insect Museum. An urgent survey should be initiated
   to determine the current distribution of the pest in Jordan. Inspection
   of ornamental nurseries should be given priority and plant protection
   officials should pay particular attention to this serious pest.

TI Barbus urmianus a new species from Urmia Lake basin, Iran (Teleostei:
   Cyprinidae).
AU Eagderi, Soheil (soheil.eagderi@ut.ac.ir) 
   Nikmehr, Nasrin
   Cicek, Erdogan
   Esmaeili, Hamid Reza
   Vatandoust, Saber
   Mousavi-Sabet, Hamed
SO International Journal of Aquatic Biology-IJAB
VL 7
IS 4
PS 239-244
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Barbus urmianus from the Mahabad-Chai River in Urmia Lake basin, is
   distinguished from its congeners in the B. lacerta group by a
   well-developed middle pad of the lower lip, a shorter postdorsal length
   (25.2-42.0 vs. 46.4-60.7% SL), long anal fin (11.0-23.0 vs. 6.0-10.4%
   SL), short dorsal-fin base (9.2-15.6 vs. 16.1-22.6% SL), less scales in
   the caudal peduncle (14-23 vs. 25-35), and 64-85 scales on the lateral
   line (vs. 52-70).

DT Article
TI The land snail fauna of a South American rainforest biodiversity
   hotspot: the Panguana conservation area in the Peruvian Amazon.
AU Wendebourg, Birte
   Hausdorf, Bernhard (hausdorf@zoologie.uni-hamburg.de) 
SO Journal of Molluscan Studies
VL 85
IS 3
PS 298-305
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 2
U2 7
AB We investigated the land snail fauna of the Panguana conservation area
   on the western rim of the Amazonas basin in Peru. A total of 2,322
   individuals assigned to 65 land snail species were collected in 32
   plots. Ten additional species were found in collections made on previous
   expeditions to Panguana. On the basis of available data, Panguana is the
   most species rich locality for land snails in South America. The species
   density of 75 land snail species in c. 2 km2 of rather homogeneous
   rainforest is also high on a global scale. The land snail fauna of
   Panguana is characterized by a very high proportion of species belonging
   to the carnivorous family Scolodontidae, many of which are likely to be
   new to science. The fauna includes seven species that are new records
   for Peru, and the species Hirtudiscus sp., Xenodiscula venezuelensis,
   Geostilbia aperta, Guppya gundlachii and Thysanophora plagioptycha
   represent genera not previously recorded from the country. The
   synanthropic species Allopeas gracile, Opeas hannense, Subulina octona,
   Geostilbia aperta and Gastrocopta servilis form an ecologically distinct
   group that occurs mainly in sites strongly modified by humans. The
   presence of these species on the margin of the Amazon rainforest is
   evidence of the ongoing homogenization of the global fauna.

   Hamburg, D-20146, Germany, Germany.
EM hausdorf@zoologie.uni-hamburg.de

OI Hausdorf, Bernhard/0000-0002-1604-1689

   Panguana conservation area / ].

   Thysanophora; Thysanophora (Lyroconus) plagioptycha; Xenodiscula;
   Xenodiscula venezuelensis [Peru /  / New record].

DT Article
TI Systematics of the subfamily Aclyvolvinae (Caenogastropoda: Ovulidae)
   based on molecular and morphometric analyses.
AU Reijnen, Bastian T.
   van der Meij, Sancia E.T. (Sancia.van.der.Meij@rug.nl) 
SO Journal of Molluscan Studies
VL 85
IS 3
PS 336-347
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Molecular phylogenetic research on the octocoral-associated gastropod
   family Ovulidae is still in its infancy and, as a consequence, the
   relationships between subfamilies and genera are not well defined.
   Previous research on various ovulid genera has shown that their
   conchological characters are often too fluid when dealing with species
   delimitations. For this study, Ovulidae were collected in Indonesia and
   Malaysia, with some additional specimens obtained from Thailand and the
   Red Sea. Relationships between the Aclyvolvinae and other ovulid
   subfamilies were assessed using sequence data from two mitochondrial
   genes (cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COI) and 16S rRNA); the dataset
   contained ovulid species (including type species) from the subfamilies
   Eocypraeinae, Ovulinae, Pediculariinae and Simniinae. The type species
   of the subfamilies Eocypraeinae and Sulcocypraeinae are fossils, and
   hence could not be included in the analyses. The phylogeny and
   systematics of the subfamily Aclyvolvinae were assessed based on four
   DNA gene regions (mitochondrial COI and 16S rRNA, and nuclear 28S rRNA
   and histone H3) and morphometric analyses. Shell morphological
   characters were analysed to help clarify species delimitations within
   the Aclyvolvinae. The results from the molecular analyses showed that
   the subfamilies Aclyvolvinae, Eocypraeinae and Simniinae are
   polyphyletic, whereas the Ovulinae and Pediculariinae appear to be
   monophyletic. Within the subfamily Aclyvolvinae, the type species of
   Hiatavolva, H. depressa, did not form a clade with the other species of
   Hiatavolva. Instead, H. Rugosa and H. coarctata formed a clade that is
   sister to the clade comprising Aclyvolva lamyi, A. lanceolata and A.
   nicolamassierae, and are therefore now considered as belonging to the
   genus Aclyvolva. Aclyvolva lamyi and A. nicolamassierae were shown to be
   synonyms of A. lanceolata, and A. Rugosa (n. comb.) is a synonym of A.
   coarctata (n. comb.). The genus Kuroshiovolva could not be retrieved in
   a fixed phylogenetic position within the Aclyvolvinae, nor did it
   cluster with H. depressa or Aclyvolva spp. Our morphometric analyses are
   in agreement with the results of the molecular analyses, and furthermore
   show that juvenile shells are morphologically significantly different
   from their adult conspecifics. Photographs of the type material of
   Ovulum lanceolatum, O. coarctatum, Neosimnia lamyi, Hiata Rugosa and A.
   nicolamassierae are provided, and new information is given on the
   geographical distribution and host species of Aclyvolvinae. The
   subfamily Aclyvolvinae is redefined and now includes only A. lanceolata
   and A. coarctata. The genus Hiatavolva is now monotypic, containing only
   H. depressa, but the subfamily to which this genus belongs remains
   unclear. Kuroshiovolva is not part of the Aclyvolvinae, but its
   subfamily level placement is unclear.
C1 van der Meij, Sancia E.T.; Naturalis Biodivers Ctr, Marine Biodivers
   Grp, Darwinweg 2, Leiden, NL-2333 CR, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM Sancia.van.der.Meij@rug.nl
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 0260-1230
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Biometrics; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Shell; Genetics; Evolution; Marine zones
DE Aclyvolvinae [Biometrics / Morphometrics / systematics] [Shell
   morphology /  / ] [Molecular genetics / DNA sequences / ] [Phylogeny /
   Molecular phylogeny / ] [Indian Ocean / Indo-Pacific / distribution]
   [Pacific Ocean /  / ]. 
   Ovulidae [Molecular genetics / DNA sequences / systematics] [Phylogeny /
   Molecular phylogeny / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda,
   Cypraeoidea
OR Aclyvolva - Cate 1973 (Cypraeoidea): [Emended diagnosis, P. 345]. 
   Aclyvolva coarctata - (Sowerby II in Adams & Reeve 1848) (Cypraeoidea):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Hiatavolva, p. 345; Syn nov, Hiatavolva
   rugosa Lorenz & Fehse 2009, p. 346]. 
   Aclyvolva lanceolata - (Sowerby II 1848) (Cypraeoidea): [Syn nov,
   Aclyvolva lamyi (Schilder 1932), p. 345; Syn nov, Aclyvolva
   nicolamassierae Fehse 1999, p. 345]. 
   Aclyvolvinae - Fehse 2007 (Cypraeoidea). 
   Hiatavolva - Cate 1973 (Cypraeoidea): [Emended diagnosis, P. 346;
   Taxonomic position, Subfamily incertae sedis, p. 346]. 
   Hiatavolva coarctata - (Sowerby II in Adams & Reeve 1848) (Cypraeoidea):
   [Referred to, Aclyvolva, p. 345]. 
   Kuroshiovolva - Azuma & Cate 1971 (Cypraeoidea): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   346; Taxonomic position, Subfamily incertae sedis, p. 345]. 
   Ovulidae - Fleming 1822 (Cypraeoidea). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15602010409
OA Other Gold

TI Synonymization of Uromacer Ricardinii Peracca, 1897 with Dendrophis
   aurata Schlegel, 1837 (Reptilia: Squamata: Colubridae: Dipsadinae), a
   Rare South American Snake with a Disjunct Distribution.
AU Hoogmoed, Marinus S. (marinus@museu-goeldi.br) 
   Fernandes, Ronaldo
   Kucharzewski, Christoph
   Moura-Leite, Julio Cesar
   Bernils, Renato S.
   Entiauspe-Neto, Omar Machado
   Regos dos Santos, Filipe Pereira
SO South American Journal of Herpetology
VL 14
IS 2
PS 88-102
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 2
U2 2
AB On the basis of direct comparisons of type material, literature data,
   and a sample of 47 other specimens examined, we synonymize Uromacer
   Ricardinii, described from Sao Paulo, Brazil, with Dendrophis aurata,
   described from Suriname and never found there again. This taxon now will
   be known as Cercophis auratus. Additionally, we redescribe the species
   and provide a detailed synonymy/chresonomy. Finally, we briefly discuss
   its disjunct distribution, as well as current knowledge of its
   conservation status.

TI A New Species of Phymaturus (Squamata: Liolaemidae) from the Auca
   Mahuida Natural Protected Area, Neuquen, Argentina, Based on
   Morphological and DNA Evidence.
AU Hibbard, Thomas N. (thomashibbard89@gmail.com) 
   Nenda, Santiago J.
   Lobo, Fernando
SO South American Journal of Herpetology
VL 14
IS 2
PS 123-135
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The number of species of the genus Phymaturus has increased consistently
   since 1995, when only 10 species had been described. Over the last two
   decades, this number has risen to 46. This group of lizards is
   characterized by a flattened body and spiny tail; they are viviparous
   and herbivorous and inhabit rocky regions, using crevices as refuges.
   For the present study, an integrative taxonomy approach was used with
   the aim of rigorously assessing the taxonomic status of a population
   occupying the Auca Mahuida volcanic field. Evidence from genetics,
   morphology, and biogeography suggests that this population is a separate
   lineage from all described species. This new species can be
   distinguished from close relatives by a longitudinal white dorsal line
   along the midline at the base of the tail. Special emphasis was put on
   determining if this taxon presented differences from the nearest
   relatives of the palluma group: P. roigorum and P. tromen. Consistent
   differences were found.
C1 Hibbard, Thomas N.; Univ Nacl Salta, Fac Ciencias Nat, Ave Bolivia 5150,
   Salta, RA-4400, Argentina, Argentina.
EM thomashibbard89@gmail.com

DT Article
TI Winter abundance of shorebirds on Humboldt Bay, California, USA.
AU Colwell, Mark A. (mac3@humboldt.edu) 
   Feucht, Elizabeth J.
   Polevy, Chelsea
SO Wader Study
VL 126
IS 2
PS 116-124
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Estimates of population size are the foundation of conservation actions;
   they facilitate identification of important habitats and provide
   evidence of population growth. We conducted four high-tide, winter (4
   Nov 2018-17 Feb 2019) surveys of Humboldt Bay, California, a site of
   Hemispheric importance under the Western Hemisphere Shorebird Reserve
   Network (WHSRN), to provide estimates of shorebird abundance. Observers
   detected 25 species totaling approximately 42,500-72,500 individuals.
   Five species that foraged on expansive unconsolidated sediments of tidal
   flats dominated the assemblage (Dunlin Calidris alpina, 40%; Western
   Sandpiper C. mauri, 26%; Least Sandpiper C. minutilla, 13%; Marbled
   Godwit Limosa fedoa, 11%); by contrast, species frequenting rocky
   intertidal habitats or ocean-fronting beaches comprised <10% of
   observations. Ranked abundances of species correlated highly across
   surveys. For most species, abundance estimates are similar to those
   reported 25 years ago. Our findings confirm the importance of Humboldt
   Bay as an estuary that hosts a diverse and abundant winter shorebird
   assemblage along the Pacific Americas Flyway.
C1 Colwell, Mark A.; Humboldt State Univ, Wildlife Dept, Arcata, CA, 95521,
   USA, USA.
EM mac3@humboldt.edu
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Biodiversity &Conservation;
   Marine &Freshwater Biology
BD Animals and man; Conservation; Ecology; Population dynamics; Habitat;
   Brackish habitat; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Charadrii [Disturbance by man / Human activities / ] [Conservation
   measures / Conservation implications / ] [Community structure /  / ]
   [Population size /  / ] [Estuary /  / ] [California / Humboldt Bay
   Estuary / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI A New Fossil Erinaceidae from the Shajingyi Area in the Lanzhou Basin,
   China.
AU Li, Zhichao (lzc_369@126.com) 
   Li, Yongxiang
   Xue, Xiangxu
   Li, Wenhou
   Zhang, Yunxiang
   Yang, Fu
SO Acta Geologica Sinica English Edition
VL 93
IS 4
PS 789-798
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Here, we describe a new primitive Erinaceidae species, Oligoechinus
   lanzhouensis n. gen. n. sp., based on a specimen from late Oligocene
   strata of the Lanzhou Basin, Gansu Province. Its characteristics are as
   follows: the M1 width is longer than the length, the metastyle extends
   far disto-labially, the posterior margin has strong curve and a distinct
   metaconule that is connected to the protocone by a postprotocrista is
   located in the centre of the tooth. The posterior arm of the metaconule
   is poorly developed. In the P4, the pterion of the metastyle is less
   developed and the metacone is carinate. In addition, O. lanzhouensis has
   a premolar larger than the canine tooth (P2 > C) and P3 had no
   molarisation, characters also possessed by Erinaceus. Overall, O.
   lanzhouensis was similar to Mioechinus based on architectural tooth
   features, demonstrating a closed genetic relationship. Fossil
   Erinaceidae are relatively rare before the Miocene. The discovery of O.
   lanzhouensis provides an important insight into the origin of Mioechinus
   in China and the early evolution of the Erinaceidae. Our analysis shows
   that a relatively recent ancestor of Mioechinus had probably existed in
   the early Oligocene and that O. Lanzhouensis was likely an ancestral
   type of Mioechinus gobiensis, and its systematic position should be
   located at a transitional position between Amphechinus and Mioechinus.
C1 Li, Zhichao; Changan Univ, Sch Earth Sci & Resources, Xian, Shaanxi,
   710054, China, China.
EM lzc_369@126.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0361-6886
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Oligoechinus [Oligocene /  / New genus]. 
   Oligoechinus lanzhouensis [Gansu /  / new species] [Oligocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Insectivores; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Insectivora, Erinaceidae

   species Oligoechinus lanzhouensis, p. 790, Oligocene; Fossil]. 
   Oligoechinus lanzhouensis (Erinaceidae): [Sp nov, Gansu, Oligocene, P.
   790; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15601006276

AN ZOOR15601005906
DT Article
TI Early wood-boring 'mole roach' reveals eusociality "missing ring".
AU Vrsansky, Peter (geolvrsa@savba.ka) 
   Koubova, Ivana
   Vrsanska, Lucia
   Hinkelman, Jan
   Kudela, Matus
   Kudelova, Tatiana
   Liang, Jun-Hui
   Xia, Fangyuan
   Lei, Xiaojie
   Ren, Xiaoyin
   Vidlicka, Lubomir
   Bao, Tong
   Ellenberger, Sieghard
   Smidova, Lucia
   Barclay, Maxwell
SO AMBA Projekty
VL 9
IS 1
PS 28pp.
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
UR https://www.phylonimbus.com/references/journal/1853/amba-projekty/
AW https://www.researchgate.net/publication/335368199_EARLY_WOOD-BORING_'MO
   LE_ROACH'_REVEALS_EUSOCIALITY_MISSING_RING
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The earliest eusociality of cockroaches is conserved in termites. New
   wood-boring mole roaches from Cretaceous Burmite belong to a new, most
   primitive, termite family Pabuonqedidae. Cock-roach symplesiomorphies
   include hypognathous head concealed under pronotum/ paranotalia, regular
   wing venation, clavus, long cercal sensillae, carinated legs,
   unspecialized tarsi, cerci and mouthparts. Venation schemes, moniliform
   antennae and hexagonal feces (n=940; l/wave= 0.30/ 0.19 mm) are termite
   synapomorphies. Cracked body surface and structure of forelegs are
   unique. Eusociality is indicated by 6 larvae preserved together, a larva
   amber-embedded inside a wood tunnel and nuptial-flight-related wing
   shedding sutures of adult females (one dealate). Nine-teen syninclusions
   include a true termite, an archaeognathan bristletail, a wood boring
   caterpillar, 9 mites - one attached parasitic. The new species exhibits
   the first transitional form leading to true sociality. Mesozoic
   all-termite phylogeny reveals a basal (explosively-appearing)
   diversification ring resulting from general fluid Bauplan tunings to
   simple reductions from a single tran-sitional taxon.
C1 Vrsansky, Peter; Institute of Zoology, Slovak Academy of Sciences,

PT J
AN ZOOR15601003244
DT Article
TI Regional characteristics of zooplankton as food for juvenile chum salmon
   Oncorhynchus keta in the coastal waters around Hokkaido, with special
   reference to copepod community structure.
AU Hirakawa, Kazumasa (info@plankton-science.jp) 
   Kaga, Toshiki
   Sato, Tomoki
   Kasai, Hiromi
SO Bulletin of Plankton Society of Japan
VL 66
IS 2
PS 72-85
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA Japanese
U1 1
U2 1
AB We investigated regional differences of zooplankton-especially the
   community structure of copepods-as an important food for juvenile chum
   salmon (Oncorhynchus keta) in the coastal waters around Hokkaido, using
   multivariate statistical techniques. Zooplankton samples were collected
   by vertical hauls from 20 m depth or, at shallower stations, from
   near-bottom to the surface using a Norpac net (mesh opening: 0.33 mm) at
   four sampling sites (regions); Atsuta (JS: Hokkaido Sea of Japan), Shari
   (OH: Okhotsk), Shiraoi (WP: West Hokkaido Pacific) and Konbumori (EP:
   East Hokkaido Pacific) in spring and summer 2007. Copepod community
   structure was classified into three clusters (F2,121=65.8, p<0.001) that
   contained significantly different indicator species compositions:
   Cluster 1, "cold water-neritic/oceanic group," was characterized by
   Neocalanus plumchrus, Eucalanus bungii, Acartia tumida, Pseudocalanus
   minutus, Pseudocalanus newmani, Calanus glacialis and Neocalanus
   flemingeri. Cluster 2, "cold/warm water-neritic/oceanic group," was
   characterized by Mesocalanus tenuicornis, Oithona atlantica, Tortanus
   discaudatus, Paracalanus sp., Clausocalanus pergens, Metridia pacifica
   and Corycaeus affinis. Cluster 3, "cold water-neritic group," was
   characterized by Acartia longiremis, Centro pages abdominalis and
   Eurytemora herdmani. Food conditions of juvenile chum salmon were better
   in Cluster 1 ("cold water-neritic/oceanic group") than in the other
   groups. Cluster 1 copepods had a greater mean copepod abundance
   (F2,121,=12.11, p<0.001) and were represented by large, lipid-rich N.
   plumchrus. Furthermore, while copepods in Cluster 2 had small-medium
   bodies, their mean abundance was substantially lower than that of
   Cluster 1. Similarly, the relatively abundant Cluster 3 co-pepods were
   much smaller in size than those of Cluster 1, which resulted in less
   available biomass for juvenile chum salmon. Comparing relationships
   between the spatiotemporal distributions of three clusters and
   hydrographic conditions (surface temperature and water mass structure)
   at each site, feeding conditions of juvenile salmon may be regionally
   evaluated as follows: favorable in EP (mostly Cluster 1 in Konbumori),
   unfavorable in JS (exclusively Cluster 2 in Atsuta) and seasonally
   variable in OH/WP (a mixture of three clusters in Shari/Shiraoi). For
   Japanese juvenile chum salmon migrating eastwards into the Sea of
   Okhotsk along the Pacific coast of Hokkaido, summer coastal
   environmental conditions off Konbumori (EP) on their assumed migration
   route may play an important role in improving feeding conditions for
   their growth, which have deteriorated because of changes in the copepod
   community structure (that is, from "cold water-neritic/oceanic group" to
   "cold water-neritic group"), the early disappearance of N. plumchrus and
   higher surface temperatures (>13[degree]C) in Shiraoi (WP).
C1 Hirakawa, Kazumasa; Japan Fisheries Res & Educ Agcy, Nishi Ku, Queens
   Tower B,2-3-3 Minato Mirai, Yokohama, Kanagawa, 2206115, Japan, Japan.
EM info@plankton-science.jp
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Nutrition
   &Dietetics
SN 0387-8961
BD Biometrics; Nutrition; Diet; Prey; Ecology; Predators; Abiotic factors;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Copepoda [Size / Body size / plankton] [Community structure /  / ]
   [Piscean predators / Oncorhynchus keta / ] [Environmental indicators /
   Bioindicators / ] [North Pacific / Japan, Hokkaido / ]. 
   Oncorhynchus keta [Crustacean prey / Copepoda / juvenile] [Abiotic
   factors / Environmental factors / ] [North Pacific / Japan, Hokkaido /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Chordates; Crustaceans; Fish; Invertebrates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces,
   Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii, Salmoniformes, Salmonidae
OR Copepoda (Crustacea): [Prey]. 
   Oncorhynchus keta (Salmonidae): [Predator]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15601003244

DT Article
TI Description of a New Species of Conus (Gastropoda: Conidae) from the
   Montebello Islands of the North West of Western Australia.
AU Morrison, Hugh M. (shellds1@iinet.net.au) 
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 3-10
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Conus jonsingletoni n. sp. is described from the area surrounding the
   Montebello Islands, lying approximately 100 kilometres west of the town
   of Dampier, north west Western Australia. It is compared with Conus
   recluzianus BERNARDI, 1853, Conus tribblei WALLS, 1977, Conus
   reductaspiralis WALLS, 1979 and Conus nielsenae MARSH, 1962. Conus
   jonsingletoni n. sp. differs from all other species of Conidae by having
   a smooth body whorl with straight sides, a sharp keel-like shoulder, a
   low and flat spire with only the protoconch and first 4 teleoconch
   whorls raised and with radiating rays of brown over the spire in sharp
   contrast to the orange/yellow colour of the body whorl.
C1 Morrison, Hugh M.; Western Australian Museum, 5 Ealing Mews, Kingsley
   Perth, WA, 6026, Australia, Australia.
EM shellds1@iinet.net.au
SC Zoology
SN 1869-5302

   New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Conoidea
OR Conus jonsingletoni (Conoidea): [Sp nov, Australia, Western Australia
   (marine), P. 4].

TI Amphidromus huynhanhi, a New Species (Gastropoda: Camaenidae) from Laos.
AU Nguyen Ngoc Thach (thachshells267@yahoo.com) 
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 11-14
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Amphidromus ALBERS, 1850 is described from
   Attapeu, Laos and compared to four other species of this genus:
   Amphidromus dubius FULTON, 1896, Amphidromus huberi THACH 2014,
   Amphidromus everetti FULTON, 1896 and Amphidromus columellaris
   MOLLENDORFF, 1892. It is characterized by a broad, intermittent spiral
   band at the base and wide axial stripes that are bisected or narrowing
   at the posterior part of each whorl.

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Genus Bothriembryon (Gastropoda:
   Bothriembryontidae) from the Shire of Esperance, Western Australia.
AU Morrison, Hugh M. (shelldsl@iinet.net.au) 
   Schneider, Ben
   Whisson, Corey S.
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 15-24
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Bothriembryon (B.) fragilis n. sp. is described from the Beaumont
   locality in the Shire of Esperance in south eastern Western Australia.
   It is compared with the sympatric species B. (B.) balteolus IREDALE,
   1939, B. (B.) dux PFEIFFER, 1861, B. (B.) distinctus IREDALE, 1939 and
   with the closest congener species B. (B.) toolinna SCHNEIDER&MORRISON,
   2018. Bothriembryon (B.) fragilis n. sp. differs from all other species
   within the genus Bothriembryon PILSBRY, 1894 by the combination of a
   small but slender profile, a thin, exceedingly fragile shell, sculptured
   periostracum, prominent raised protoconch and distinct spiral cording of
   the teleconch whorls.

TI Contributions to the knowledge of the Ovulidae, XXVII. New Generic

AU Fehse, Dirk (triviidae@gmail.com) 
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 33-38
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A problem with the parsimony tree of SCHIAPARELLI et al. (2005: text
   fig. 1) is solved by the assignment of Primovula piriei PETUCH, 1973 to
   the genus Amonovula n. gen. Exclusively studying the shell outline or
   the coloration of the species cannot confirm any relations between taxa
   and genera.

TI A New Species of Conidae from Taiwan (Gastropoda).

   Barbier, Jean Pierre

U1 0
U2 0
AB Profundiconus weii n. sp. from Taiwanese deep water superficially
   resembles P. dondani (KOSUGE, 1981) and P. lani (CRANDALL, 1979) in
   shape but differs by the absence of darker pattern and more widely
   spaced and more developed axial ridges on the body whorl.

DT Article
TI Contributions to the knowledge of the Ovulidae, XXVIII. On the Identity
   of Ovulum formosum G. B. Sowerby II, 1848 and Description of a New
   Cuspivolva.
AU Fehse, Dirk (triviidae@gmail.com) 
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 47-53
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the gastropod family Ovulidae FLEMING, 1828 is
   described from the Philippines. It is assigned to the genus Cuspivolva
   C. N. CATE, 1973. Type species of the genus is Cuspivolva cuspis (C. N.
   CATE, 1973). The wrongly interpreted Ovulum formosum is assigned herein
   to the genus Primovula THIELE, 1925 and Delonovolva C. N. CATE, 1973
   becomes its junior synonym. The common interpretation of O. formosum is
   described as Cuspivolva pulcherrima n. sp. and is discussed with similar
   taxa of the genus.

   Munchhausenstr 21, Munich, D-81247, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI An Overlooked Second Species of Thatcheria from Western Australia
   (Gastropoda: Conoidea: Raphitomidae).
AU Lorenz, Felix (felix.lorenz@t-online.de) 
   Stahlschmidt, Peter
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 55-62
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Thatcheria janae n. sp. from Northwestern Australia differs from the
   Pacific T mirabilis ANGAS, 1877 by a lower shell mass, a paler
   coloration, and a thinner, more angular carinal keel, which is nodulose
   instead of smooth in the first three teleoconch whorls in many
   specimens. Differences in the relative shell's width/length ratio, and
   the slightly inflated instead of straight body whorl are obvious when
   comparing larger series of specimens.

DT Article
TI A New Species of Conidae (Gastropoda) from the Egyptian Red Sea.
AU Lorenz, Felix (felix.lorenz@t-online.de) 
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 63-66
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Isoconus kahlbrocki n. sp. from the northern Red Sea has been mistaken
   for Leptoconus hamanni (FAIN-ZILBER&MIENIS, 1986) from the same general
   area and depth. It differs by its color pattern and the lower spire. It
   is more slender than Isoconus martensi (E. A. SMITH, 1884) from the
   western Indian Ocean. It is more similar to the Pacific Isoconus sazanka
   (SHIKAMA, 1970), from which it differs by a more slender shape and a
   taller spire with a more conspicuous protoconch.
C1 Lorenz, Felix; Friedrich Ebert Str 12, Buseck Beuern, D-35418, Germany,
   Germany.

DT Article
TI Two New Species of Conidae (Gastropoda) from Mauritius.
AU Lorenz, Felix (felix.lorenz@t-online.de) 
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 67-74
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pionoconus marysae n. sp. from Mauritius differs from the Pacific P.
   aurisiacus (LINNAEUS, 1758) by being a smaller, more ventricose, and
   less sharply shouldered shell with a cancellate dorsal surface
   sculpture. The sympatric P. barthelemyi (BERNARDI, 1861) is
   superficially similar in colour pattern but is smooth and has a flatter
   spire. Darioconus brandonensis n. sp. differs from D. episcopus (HWASS
   in BRUGUIERE, 1792) by the distinctly narrower shell, a finer pattern
   with numerous white specks, and a conspicuous pink protoconch. It is
   also compared to D. pennaceus (BORN, 1778) and D. omaria (HWASS in
   BRUGUIERE, 1792).
C1 Lorenz, Felix; Friedrich Ebert Str 12, Buseck Beuern, D-35418, Germany,
   Germany.
EM felix.lorenz@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 1869-5302

DE Darioconus brandonensis; Pionoconus marysae [South Indian Ocean /
   Mauritius / New species].

ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Conoidea
OR Darioconus brandonensis (Conoidea): [Sp nov, Mauritius (marine), P. 68].

TI Description of a new Ferussacia from Fuerteventura, Canary Islands,
   Spain (Gastropoda, Pulmonata: Ferussaciidae).
AU Groh, Klaus (klaus.groh@conchbooks.com) 
   Henkel, Hubert
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 117-124
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The ground-dwelling species Ferussacia martinae n. sp. is described from
   Quaternary sand deposits of probably upper Pleistocene age from the
   Jandia Peninsula of Fuerteventura, Canary Islands. It is compared with
   the extant Ferussaciidae species from Fuerteventura. The new species
   clearly differs from Ferussacia submajor (WOLLASTON, 1878) by its wider
   shell and from Sculptiferussacia? clausiliaeformis ALONSO&IBANEZ, 1992
   and Ferussacia valida (MOUSSON, 1872) by its smaller size and less
   developed radial ribbing. The generic status of both genera on the
   Canary Islands is being discussed.

TI A New Species of Morum from the Diaoyu Islands (East China Sea)
   (Gastropoda: Harpidae).
AU Monsecour, David (david.monsecour@telenet.be) 
   Lorenz, Felix
   Monsecour, Kevin
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 125-128
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Morum lathraeum n. sp. from Uotsuri-shima / Diaoyu Dao (Diaoyu Islands),
   East China Sea is described and compared with superficially similar
   congeners. The new species is defined by a faint axial sculpture of few
   narrow ribs, a prominent spiral sculpture on the body whorl, a high
   spire consisting of roundly shouldered whorls, a semi-detached
   columellar plait with numerous, sometimes somewhat elongated pustules
   and a denticulate inner lip with teeth of variable strength.

TI Description of Two New Species of the Genus Bothriembryon (Gastropoda,
   Pulmonata: Bothriembryontidae) from the Fitzgerald River National Park
   on the South Coast of Western Australia.
AU Morrison, Hugh M. (shelldsl@iinet.net.au) 
   Schneider, Ben
SO Conchylia
VL 50
IS 1-4
PS 129-142
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Bothriembryon (B.) whissoni n. sp. and B. (B.) diversicolor n. sp. are
   described from the area surrounding East Mount Barren at the eastern
   extremity of the Fitzgerald River National Park, northwest of Hopetoun
   on the south coast of Western Australia. Bothriembryon (B.) whissoni n.
   sp. is compared with its closest congener species, B. (B.) sophiarum
   WHISSON&BREURE, 2016. B. (B.) diversicolor n. sp. is compared with its
   sister species B. (B.) melo (QUOY&GAIMARD, 1832). Both species are also
   compared with the sympatric species B. (B.) dux (L. PFEIFFER, 1861) and
   the most easterly forms of B. (B.) kingii (J. E. GRAY, 1825). B. (B.)
   whissoni n. sp. differs from all other species within the genus
   Bothriembryon PILSBRY, 1894 by the combination of small slender profile,
   white spotted upper protoconch and teleoconch whorls, fine spiral cords
   over the entire surface and a smooth, non-crenulated suture. B. (B.)
   diversicolor n. sp. can be separated from other members of the genus by
   its small but inflated profile, short beaded axial ribs extending
   abapically from the suture and by a darkly stained umbilicus.

AB Acanthococcus mokanae Gonzalez, Ramos&Caballero sp. nov. is described
   from specimens associated with Hibiscus sp. (Malvaceae) and Capsicum sp.
   (Solanaceae), in the departments of Atlantico and Cordoba (Colombia,
   South America). Uhleria araucariae (Maskell) is recorded for the first
   time in Colombia in association with Araucaria heterophylla (Salisb.)
   (Araucariaceae) and Cryptomeria japonica (Thunb. Ex L.f.)
   (Cupressaceae). A taxonomic key for eriococcids recorded from Colombia
   based on the external morphology of the adult female is provided.

TI NEW RECORDS OF THREE DEEP-SEA BATHYMODIOLUS MUSSELS (BIVALVIA: MYTILIDA:
   MYTILIDAE) FROM HYDROTHERMAL VENT AND COLD SEEPS IN TAIWAN.
AU Kuo, Meng-Ying
   Kang, Dun-Ru
   Chang, Chih-Hsien
   Chao, Chia-Hsien
   Wang, Chau-Chang
   Chen, Hsin-Hung
   Su, Chih-Chieh
   Chen, Hsuan-Wien
   Lai, Mei-Chin
   Lin, Saulwood
   Liu, Li-Lian (lilian@mail.nsysu.edu.tw) 
SO Journal of Marine Science and Technology
VL 27
IS 4
PS 352-358
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 3
U2 4
AB The deep sea mussel genus, Bathymodiolus Kenk&Wilson, 1985, contains 31
   species, worldwide. Of which, one endemic species (Bathymodiolus
   taiwanesis) was reported from Taiwan (MolluscaBase, 2018). Herein, based
   on the mitochondrial COI results, we present 3 new records of the
   Bathymodiolus species from Taiwan, namely Bathymodiolus platifrons,
   Bathymodiolus securforrnis, and Sissano Bathymodiolus sp.1 which were
   collected from vent or seep environments at depth ranges of 1080-1380 m.
   Therefore, a total of four species in the genus of Bathymodiolus are now
   known from Taiwan.

   Taiwan.

TI Fossil decapod crustaceans from the Early Cretaceous (Albian) of Oregon,
   USA.
AU Nyborg, Torrey (tnyborg06g@llu.edu) 
   Garassino, Alessandro
   Vega, Francisco J.
   Kovalchuk, Gregory
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 293
IS 2
PS 127-138
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Three new species of fossil decapod crustaceans are reported from the
   Early Cretaceous (Albian) Hudspeth Formation of central Oregon.
   Dromiopsis oscari n. sp. represents the oldest species of Dromiopsis in
   North America. Glaessnerella yamoori n. sp. represents the f rst report
   for the genus outside of Europe. Eodorippe connori n. sp. represents the
   oldest record for the genus. Finally, Hoploparia riddlensis FELDMANN,
   1974 is reported from the Hudspeth Formation, enlarging the
   stratigraphic range of this species limited to date to the Hauterivian
   of the Days Creek Formation (Riddle, Douglas Co., Oregon).

DT Article
TI Cretaceous Decapoda (Crustacea) from Mississippi, USA.
AU Schweitzer, Carrie E. (cschweit@kent.edu) 
   Feldmann, Rodney
   Phillips, George E.
   Armstrong, Adam
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 293
IS 2
PS 145-197
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Diverse Late Cretaceous assemblages of decapod crustaceans from the Gulf
   Coastal Plain, USA, have yielded numerous new taxa and new occurrences.
   New palinurid lobsters include Linuparus shacklefordae n. sp. and
   Palinurus? sauerweinorum n. sp. Among the podotrematous crabs, the
   following are new: the homoloid Ripleycarcinus primaevus n. gen., n.
   sp.; the palaeocorystoid Ripleycorystes cardwelli n. gen., n. sp.; the
   raninoid Symethoides danieli n. sp.; the dakoticancroid Tropidicarcinus
   n. gen. with two new species, T mcanallyae and T starnesi; and the
   cyclodorippoid Gyroplanus sapphirinus n. gen., n. sp. New eubrachyurans
   include the retroplumoid Archaeopus diabolus n. sp. The material is
   largely from Santonian, Campanian, and Maastrichtian sediments of
   Mississippi, although other notable occurrences are included. The new
   data suggest that localities in the North Atlantic proximal to the
   Chicxulub, Mexico, impact area suffered higher percentages of generic
   and family level decapod extinction than localities more distal to that
   area.

PT J
AN ZOOR15601005736
DT Article
TI Systematic congruence in Polycladida (Platyhelminthes, Rhabditophora):
   are DNA and morphology telling the same story?
AU Litvaitis, Marian K. (m.litvaitis@unh.edu) 
   Bolanos, D. Marcela
   Quiroga, Sigmer Y.
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 186
IS 4
PS 865-891
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 2
U2 3
AB Using 28S ribosomal DNA sequences, we inferred the internal
   relationships of the order Polycladida. We identified morphological
   characters for Glade support when possible. Monophyletic Acotylea and
   Cotylea were consistently recovered. In Acotylea, the superfamilies
   Stylochoidea, Cryptoceloidea and Leptoplanoidea were supported, with
   Stylochoidea representing the most basal acotylean lineage. In
   Leptoplanoidea, we united genera lacking a penis armature into the new
   family Notocomplanidae. Gnesiocerotidae was recovered as the most basal
   leptoplanoid lineage, and Stylochoplanidae and Notoplanidae were
   paraphyletic. Among cotyleans, Cestoplanidae, Diposthus popeae +
   Pericelis spp., Boniniidae, Pseudocerotidae and Prosthiostomidae formed
   clades. Genera in Euryleptidae were monophyletic, but the family itself
   was recovered with low support only. The established superfamilies
   Pseudocerotoidea, Euryleptoidea, Periceloidea and Chromoplanoidea are
   not supported. Pericelis has been moved to Diposthidae and Pericelidae
   has been abolished. A Glade of Boniniidae + Theama spp. + Chromyella sp.
   was supported. In Pseudocerotidae, the number of male reproductive
   structures unites Pseudobiceros and Thysanozoon. Tytthosoceros has been
   abolished, with all currently described species now placed in
   Phrikoceros. Our results support several additional synonymies and
   taxonomic corrections. This new phylogeny provides an increased
   understanding of relationships in the order and offers a framework for
   future testing of hypotheses of character evolution and life-history
   strategies.
C1 Litvaitis, Marian K.; Univ New Hampshire, Dept Nat Resources & Environm,
   56 Coll Rd, Durham, NH, 03824, USA, USA.
EM m.litvaitis@unh.edu
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 0024-4082
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Diagnosis; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; General morphology; Life cycle
   and development; Genetics; Evolution
DE Polycladida [General morphology /  / taxonomic revision] [Life cycle /
   Life history / ] [Molecular genetics / 28S rDNA sequences / ]
   [Evolutionary adaptation /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Platyhelminths
ST Animalia, Platyhelminthes, Turbellaria
OR Amyris hummelincki - Marcus & Marcus 1968 (Turbellaria): [Syn nov,
   Amyris ujara Marcus & Marcus 1968, p. 878].

DT Article
TI Multilocus phylogeny, species delimitation and biogeography of Iberian
   valvatiform springsnails (Caenogastropoda: Hydrobiidae), with the
   description of a new genus.
AU Delicado, Diana
   Arconada, Beatriz
   Aguado, Amanda
   Ramos, Marian A. (m.ramos@mncn.csic.es) 
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 186
IS 4
PS 892-914
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Valvatiform gastropods of the family Hydrobiidae are frequently found in
   European spring-fed systems. Their simplified and sometimes convergent
   morphological structures and restricted geographical ranges make the
   description and identification of valvatiform species challenging. In
   the Iberian Peninsula, to date, 20 valvatiform species have been
   described morphologically. To test morphological species delimitations
   and to evaluate the role of physical geography on their evolutionary
   history, we analysed two mitochondrial (COI and 16S rRNA) and two
   nuclear (28S rRNA and 18S rRNA) gene fragments of 16 valvatiform species
   from the Iberian Peninsula. Molecular species delimitation methods
   consistently inferred 11 of the nominal species. Our phylogenetic
   analyses recovered the species Islamia azarum as an independent lineage,
   distantly related to other genera, which we place in the new genus
   Deganta. Furthermore, Iberian valvatiform hydrobiids do not form a
   monophyletic subunit, but they are included in two distinct clades of
   Hydrobiidae. Divergence times indicate that speciation in these clades
   is likely to have coincided with the formation of major Iberian mountain
   ranges and river basins. Similarities of geographical subdivision and
   divergent times between this assemblage and the non-valvatiform genus
   Corrosella provide strong evidence for the role of the Iberian
   geographical barriers in shaping the biogeography of these springsnails.
C1 Ramos, Marian A.; CSIC, Museo Nacl Ciencias Nat, Jose Gutierrez Abascal
   2, Madrid, E-28006, Spain, Spain.
EM m.ramos@mncn.csic.es

   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Genetics; Evolution;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Hydrobiidae [Molecular genetics / Nuclear & mtDNA sequences /
   systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ] [Europe
   / Iberian Peninsula / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda, Rissoidea

   Hydrobiidae, Type species Neohoratia azarum Boeters & Rolan 1988, p.
   905]. 
   Deganta azarum - (Boeters & Rolan 1988) (Rissoidea): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 905; Comb nov, Transferred from Islamia, p. 905]. 
   Hydrobiidae (Rissoidea).

DT Article
TI Unexpected diversity of Hyboserica chafers in South African forest
   remnants: cladistic analysis, new species and the new genus Leoserica
   (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Melolonthinae).
AU Fabrizi, Silvia
   Eberle, Jonas
   Ahrens, Dirk (ahrens.dirk_col@gmx.de) 
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 186
IS 4
PS 950-982
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB A taxonomic revision of Hyboserica uncovers an unexpected diversity of
   species from Southern African forest remnants. The work results in the
   description of a new genus, Leoserica gen. nov., a new combination, a
   new synonymy and 32 new species are described. The lectotypes of Serica
   capensis and Triodonta caffra are designated. The habitus and male
   genitalia of all revised species are illustrated. A species distribution
   map and an identification key to the species are provided. Phylogenetic
   analysis reveals a deep split into one very diverse eastern lade that is
   distributed north to Zimbabwe, and one western clade that is restricted
   to the fynbos of the Cape Region.

PT J
AN ZOOR15601005741
DT Article
TI A new large cynodont from the Late Permian (Lopingian) of the South
   African Karoo Basin and its phylogenetic significance.
AU Abdala, Fernando (1viutiabdala2@gmail.com) 
   Gaetano, Leandro C.
   Smith, Roger M.H.
   Rubidge, Bruce S.
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 186
IS 4
PS 983-1005
PD Aug 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB The Karoo Basin of South Africa has the best global record of Lopingian
   (Late Permian) non-mammaliaform cynodonts, currently represented by five
   species. We describe Vetusodon elikhulu gen. et sp. nov., documented by
   four specimens from the Daptocephalus Assemblage Zone. With a basal
   skull length of [approximately]18 cm, it is the largest Lopingian
   cynodont and is also larger than Induan representatives of the group.
   Vetusodon elikhulu has a cranial morphology that departs notably from
   that previously documented for Permo-Triassic cynodonts. It features a
   short and extremely wide snout, resembling that of the contemporaneous
   therocephalian Moschorhinus, and has large incisors and canines that
   contrast with the small unicusped postcanines, suggesting a more
   important role of the anterior dentition for feeding. The dentary is
   extremely long and robust, with the posterior margin located closer to
   the craniomandibular joint than in other Lopingian and Induan cynodonts
   (e.g. Thrinaxodon). The secondary palate morphology of V. elikhulu is
   unique, being short and incomplete and with the posterior portion of the
   maxilla partly covering the vomer. A phylogenetic analysis suggests that
   V. elikhulu is the sister taxon of Eucynodontia and thus the most
   derived of the Lopingian to Induan cynodonts yet discovered.
C1 Abdala, Fernando; Conicet Fdn Miguel Lillo, Unidad Ejecutora Lillo,
   Miguel Lillo 251, San Miguel De Tucuman, Tucuman, Argentina, Argentina.
EM 1viutiabdala2@gmail.com
RI Smith, Roger/AAF-7947-2019; Rubidge, Bruce/AAE-7021-2019
OI Rubidge, Bruce/0000-0003-2477-1873
SC Zoology
SN 0024-4082

   Africa; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

   Vetusodon elikhulu [South Africa /  / new species] [Permian /  / ].

ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Synapsida, Therapsida
OR Vetusodon (Therapsida): [Gen nov, Of Epicynodontia, Type species
   Vetusodon elikhulu, p. 987, Permian; Fossil]. 
   Vetusodon elikhulu (Therapsida): [Sp nov, South Africa, Permian, P. 987;
   Fossil].
